labels.text:
Excerpts from the Diamond Sutra, an important Buddhist scripture about the nature of impermanence, dominate the composition
oft his recent painting by Fong Chung-Ray, a member of the Fifth Moon Society in Taiwaninthe1960s.Thesquarely composed characters—as if copied by a child—and patches of acrylic in earthy tones were transfer-printed and layered onto the canvas
by hand. In result, thepainting’s surface resembles the patterns of ceramic crackles or the texture of dilapidated walls, bringing an aesthetic of decay. The Buddhist texts, some obscured andothers visible, aretestaments to Fong’s understanding of decay as a transient stage in the cycle of material transformations.
台灣「五月畫會」成員馮鍾睿的這幅近作，以佛教重要經典《金剛經》為素材。字體方正的經文佔據畫面，猶如孩童筆跡，一塊塊沙土色調的塑膠彩以手工轉印並層疊在畫面之上。此作品表面呈現如陶瓷裂紋或破舊牆壁的質感，不無衰朽之美。部分經文清晰可見，部分則模糊不堪，馮鍾睿視衰朽為事物演變中必經的短暫過程，在此可見一斑。

medium.en: acrylic and paper collage on canvas

inscription.en: Inscribed in ink, verso, LL quad: Painting 2014-17

images.AltText: Acrylic painting with paper collage on canvas of Chinese characters written in white across a patchwork of brown, bronze, and gold colours. Apart from the vertically written phrases—‘Namo Amitabha Buddha’, ‘If you can see the way’, and ‘Acting right is the way’—the writing is obscured by paint and paper collage
images.AltTextTC: 塑膠彩及紙拼貼布本作品，上面有棕色、青銅色和金色的拼貼及白色文字；除了以直排中文書寫的「南無阿彌陀佛」、「若得見真道」及「行正即是道」，在塑膠彩及紙拼貼下，多處文字顯得模糊。
